If the mind is equal to the mind, then enjoy staying alone in the forest.
Then the World-Honored One, from the forest grove of the monastery protector, put on his robe and took his bowl, and went to the forest grove of the monastery of Panamansha.

At that time, in the forest grove of the monastery of Panamansha, there were three clansmen who were staying together, the Venerable Anuruddha, the Venerable Nanda, and the Venerable Kimbila. The practice of those Venerables was like this.

If one of them returned from alms-round first, he would then prepare the seat, draw water, take out the foot-washing vessel, place the foot-washing stool and foot-wiping towel, the water pot, and the washbasin.
If the alms-food obtained was enough to finish eating, then they would finish eating it;
if there was any left over, they would cover and store it in a vessel.
After finishing the meal, he put away the bowl, washed his hands and feet, put the sitting mat on his shoulder, and entered the room to sit in meditation.
If there were leftovers from the alms round, if he could finish them, he would finish them all. If not enough, he would take the remaining food from before and eat it to his satisfaction.

If there were leftovers, he would pour them on the clean ground or into water without insects. He would take the eating bowl, wash it clean, and put it aside. He would put away the bed and seat, wash the foot stand, put away the foot-wiping cloth, and put away the foot-washing vessel, the water pot, and the washbasin. He would sweep and sprinkle the dining hall, clean it, put away the robes and bowls, wash his hands and feet, put the sitting mat on his shoulder, and enter the room to sit in meditation.

Those Venerables, when it was afternoon, if there was anyone who had first arisen from sitting in meditation, seeing the water pot and washing vessel empty without water, would then carry it to get water. If they were able to lift it, they would carry it back and place it to one side;

if they were unable to lift it, they would then beckon a fellow monk with their hand. The two of them would then lift it together and carry it to one side, each not speaking to the other, each not asking the other.
Those Venerables would gather once every five days, either to discuss the Dharma or to practice noble silence.
Then the forest keeper saw the World-Honored One coming from afar and tried to stop him, saying:ğŸ”½Ascetic!
Ascetic!
Do not enter this forest.
Why is that?
Now in this forest there are three clansmen, the Venerable Anuruddha, the Venerable Nandiya, and the Venerable Kimbila. If they see you, there may be something unpleasant.
The World-Honored One said:
Forest keeper!
If he sees me, he will certainly approve, there is no doubt.
Then Venerable Anuruddha saw the World-Honored One coming from afar and reprimanded him, saying:
You forest keeper!
Do not scold the World-Honored One.
You forest keeper!
Do not stop the Well-Gone One.
Why is that?
My Honored One is coming, my Well-Gone One is coming.
Venerable Anuruddha came out to greet the World-Honored One, took his robe and bowl, Venerable Nanda prepared a seat for the Buddha, and Venerable Kimbila fetched water for the Buddha.
At that time, after the World-Honored One had washed his hands and feet, he sat on the seat prepared by the Venerable One. Having sat down, he asked:
Anuruddha!
Are you always at ease and without want?
Venerable Anuruddha replied:
World-Honored One!
I am always at ease and without want.
The World-Honored One further asked Anuruddha:
Are you at ease and without want?
The Venerable Anuruddha replied:
World-Honored One!
I think like this:
'I have good benefits and great merits, in that I practice together with such pure practices.
World-Honored One!

I always practice loving-kindness with the body, seeing and not seeing, being the same without difference, practicing loving-kindness with speech, and practicing loving-kindness with the mind, seeing and not seeing, being the same without difference.
World-Honored One!
I think like this:
'Should I now abandon my own mind and follow the minds of those sages?
World-Honored One!
I then abandoned my own mind and followed the minds of those sages.
World-Honored One!
I have never had a disagreeable mind.
World-Honored One!
Thus, I am always at ease and without want.
When asked, the Venerable Nandiya also answered in the same way.
He further asked Venerable Kimbila:
Are you always at ease and without want?
Venerable Kimbila replied:
World-Honored One!
I am always at ease and without want.
He asked:
Kimbila!
How are you at ease and without want?
Venerable Kimbila replied:
World-Honored One!
I think like this:
'I have good benefits and great merits, namely that I practice together with such pure conduct.' World-Honored One!

I always practice loving-kindness with the body towards those of pure conduct, whether seen or unseen, without any difference, and practice loving-kindness with speech and mind, whether seen or unseen, without any difference.
World-Honored One!
I think like this:
'Should I now abandon my own mind and follow the minds of those virtuous ones?' World-Honored One!
I then abandoned my own mind and followed the minds of those elders.
World-Honored One!
I have never had an unhappy mind.
World-Honored One!
Thus, I am always at ease and have nothing lacking.
The World-Honored One praised:
Excellent!ğŸ”½Excellent!
Anuruddha!

In this way, you have always been harmonious, happy, without disputes, with one mind and one teacher, united like water and milk. Have you attained the Dharma of a human superior and are peacefully abiding?
The Venerable Anuruddha said:
World-Honored One!

In this way, we have always been harmonious, happy, without disputes, with one mind and one teacher, united like water and milk. We have attained the Dharma of a human superior and are peacefully abiding.
World-Honored One!
When we obtain light, we see forms, but the light of those who see forms disappears.
The World-Honored One said:
Anuruddha!
You do not understand this characteristic. You say that when you obtain light and see forms, that seeing of forms and light is extinguished.
Anuruddha!
Before I attained supreme perfect enlightenment, I also obtained light and saw forms, but that seeing of forms and light was extinguished.
Anuruddha!
I thought like this:

'What is the problem in my mind that causes me to lose concentration and lose my eyes? When the eyes are lost, the light I originally obtained to see forms, that seeing of forms and light is extinguished.'
Anuruddha!
I practiced diligently without slacking off, my body was still, I had right mindfulness and right knowledge, without delusion, and attained concentration and one-pointedness of mind.
Anuruddha!
I thought like this:

'If I were to practice diligently without slacking off, with a still body, right mindfulness, right knowledge, and no delusion, and attain concentration and one-pointedness of mind, even if there were no path in the world, could I see and know that?'
This doubt arose in my mind, and because of this doubt, I lost my concentration and my eye. When the eye disappeared, the light and vision of forms that I had attained before also disappeared.
Anuruddha!
I now must think like this:
'I will not give rise to doubt in my mind.'
Anuruddha!

Because I do not want to give rise to this affliction, I will stay in seclusion, dwell alone, be heedful, and practice diligently. Because of staying in seclusion, dwelling alone, being heedful, and practicing diligently, I will attain light and vision of forms, and that light and vision of forms will not disappear.
Anuruddha!
I further thought like this:
'What is the affliction in my mind that causes me to lose concentration and lose my eyes? When my eyes are lost, the light and vision of forms that I originally obtained are also lost.'
Aniruddha!
I further thought like this:

'Affliction of no thought arises in my mind. Because of this affliction of no thought, I lose concentration and lose my eyes. When my eyes are lost, the light and vision of forms that I originally obtained are also lost.'
Aniruddha!
I should now think like this:
'Affliction of doubt does not arise in my mind, nor does affliction of no thought arise.'
Aniruddha!

I wanted to avoid this affliction, so I stayed in seclusion, alone and focused, practicing diligently. Because I stayed in seclusion, alone and focused, practicing diligently, I attained light and saw forms, but that light and the forms I saw quickly disappeared.
Anuruddha!
I had this thought:

'What affliction is there in my mind that causes me to lose concentration and my eyes to disappear? When my eyes disappeared, the light and forms I originally attained disappeared, and that light and the forms I saw quickly disappeared.'
Anuruddha!
I had this further thought:

'There is a bodily illness in my mind, and because of this bodily illness, I lose concentration and my eyes disappear. When my eyes disappear, the light and forms I originally attain disappear, and that light and the forms I see quickly disappear.'
Anuruddha!
I should now think like this:
'There is no doubt or uncertainty in my mind, nor is there any bodily illness or pain.'
Anuruddha!

In order to avoid these afflictions, I then stayed in seclusion, dwelling alone and diligently practicing with an undistracted mind. Because of staying in seclusion, dwelling alone and diligently practicing with an undistracted mind, I attained light and saw forms, but that light and seeing of forms quickly disappeared.
Anuruddha!
I further thought:
'What affliction is there in my mind that causes me to lose concentration and lose my eyes? When my eyes disappeared, the light and seeing of forms that I originally attained quickly disappeared.'
Anuruddha!
I further thought:
'There is a sleepiness sickness in my mind, and because of this sleepiness sickness, I lose concentration and my eyes close. When my eyes close, the light and the forms I originally saw disappear.'
Anuruddha!
I now must think like this:
'I will not give rise to doubt sickness in my mind, nor will I give rise to forgetfulness sickness, nor will I give rise to bodily illness sickness, nor will I give rise to sleepiness sickness.'
Anuruddha!

Because I do not want to give rise to these sicknesses, I will dwell in seclusion, alone, with a mind free from negligence, practicing diligently. Because of dwelling in seclusion, alone, with a mind free from negligence, practicing diligently, I will attain light and see forms, and the light and forms I see will not disappear.'
Anuruddha!
I further thought like this:
'What is the problem in my mind that causes me to lose concentration and lose my eyes? After the eyes are lost, the light and vision of forms that I originally obtained are also lost.'
Anuruddha!
I then had this thought:

'The problem in my mind is excessive exertion. Because of this problem of excessive exertion, I lost concentration and lost my eyes. After the eyes are lost, the light and vision of forms that I originally obtained are also lost.'
Anuruddha!
It is just like a strong man who holds a fly too tightly, and the fly immediately dies.
In the same way, Anuruddha!

The problem in my mind is excessive exertion. Because of this problem of excessive exertion, I lost concentration and lost my eyes. After the eyes are lost, the light and vision of forms that I originally obtained are also lost.
Anuruddha!
I must now think like this:

'I do not give rise to doubts in my mind, I do not give rise to the affliction of non-thought, I do not give rise to the affliction of bodily illness, I do not give rise to the affliction of sleepiness, nor do I give rise to the affliction of excessive diligence.'
Anuruddha!
In order to not give rise to these afflictions, I then stayed in seclusion, alone and unaccompanied, with an undefiled mind, practicing diligently.
Because of staying in seclusion, alone and unaccompanied, with an undefiled mind, practicing diligently, I then attained light and saw forms, but that light and seeing of forms quickly disappeared.
Anuruddha!
I had this thought:
'What affliction is there in my mind that causes me to lose concentration and lose my eyes? When my eyes disappeared, the light and seeing of forms that I originally attained quickly disappeared.'
Anuruddha!
I had this thought again:

'Laziness arises in my mind, and because of this laziness, I lose concentration and the eye is extinguished. When the eye is extinguished, the light and vision of forms that I originally obtained are also extinguished.'
Anuruddha!
It is just like a strong man holding a fly too loosely, and the fly flies away.
Anuruddha!

Laziness arises in my mind, and because of this laziness, I lose concentration and the eye is extinguished. When the eye is extinguished, the light and vision of forms that I originally obtained are also extinguished.
Anuruddha!
I must now think like this:

'Doubt does not arise in my mind, nor do I have the affliction of lack of mindfulness, the affliction of bodily illness, the affliction of sleepiness, the affliction of excessive diligence, nor the affliction of excessive laziness.'
Anuruddha!

I wanted to avoid this affliction, so I stayed in seclusion, alone and focused, practicing diligently. Because of staying in seclusion, alone and focused, practicing diligently, I attained light and saw forms, but that light and seeing of forms disappeared again.
Anuruddha!
I had this thought:
'What affliction is in my mind that causes me to lose concentration and lose my eyes? When my eyes disappeared, the light and seeing of forms that I originally attained also disappeared.'
Anuruddha!
I had this thought:

'Fear and terror arose in my mind. Because of this fear and terror, I lost concentration and lost my eyes. When my eyes disappeared, the light and seeing of forms that I originally attained also disappeared.'
Anuruddha!
It is like a person walking on a path, with bandits coming from the four directions. Upon seeing them, they are afraid and terrified, with their body hair standing on end.
In the same way, Anuruddha!

I had fear and anxiety in my mind. Because of this fear and anxiety, I lost my concentration and my eyes closed. After the eyes closed, the light and the sight of forms that I had attained before immediately disappeared.
Anuruddha!
I must now think like this:

'I will not give rise to doubt and anxiety in my mind, nor will I give rise to lack of mindfulness, nor will I give rise to thoughts of physical illness, nor will I give rise to sleepiness, nor will I give rise to excessive diligence, nor will I give rise to excessive laziness, nor will I give rise to fear and anxiety.'
Anuruddha!

I wanted to avoid this affliction, so I stayed in seclusion, alone and focused, practicing diligently. Because I stayed in seclusion, alone and focused, practicing diligently, I attained light and saw forms, but that light and the forms I saw quickly disappeared.
Anuruddha!
I had this thought:
'What affliction is in my mind that causes me to lose concentration and lose my eyesight? When my eyesight disappeared, the light and forms I originally saw also quickly disappeared.'
Anuruddha!
I had this further thought:

'There is an affliction of joy in my mind. Because of this affliction of joy, I lost concentration and lost my eyesight. When my eyesight disappeared, the light and forms I originally saw also quickly disappeared.'
Anuruddha!
It is just like a person who originally sought one treasure trove, but suddenly obtained four treasure troves. Upon seeing them, he immediately gave rise to joy and delight.
In this way, Anuruddha!

I gave rise to joy and delight in my mind, and because of this joy and delight, I lost my concentration and my eyes disappeared. After the eyes disappeared, the light and the forms that I originally saw also disappeared.
Anuruddha!
I should now think like this:
'I should not give rise to doubts in my mind, nor should I give rise to lack of mindfulness, bodily illness, sleepiness, excessive diligence, excessive laziness, fear, or joy and delight.'
Anuruddha!

I wanted to avoid this affliction, so I stayed in seclusion, alone and focused, practicing diligently. Because I stayed in seclusion, alone and focused, practicing diligently, I attained light and saw forms, but that light and vision of forms disappeared again.
Anuruddha!
I had this thought:
'What affliction is in my mind that causes me to lose concentration and lose my eyes? When my eyes disappeared, the light and vision of forms that I originally attained also disappeared.'
Anuruddha!
I had this further thought:

'There is a sense of self-importance in my mind. Because of this sense of self-importance, I lost concentration and lost my eyes. When my eyes disappeared, the light and vision of forms that I originally attained also disappeared.'
Anuruddha!
I should now think like this:

'I do not give rise to doubts in my mind, I do not give rise to the affliction of non-thought, I do not give rise to the affliction of bodily illness, I do not give rise to the affliction of sleepiness, I do not give rise to the affliction of excessive diligence, I do not give rise to the affliction of excessive laziness, I do not give rise to the affliction of fear, I do not give rise to the affliction of joy, and I also do not give rise to the affliction of self-conceit.
' Aniruddha!

In order to not give rise to these afflictions, I then stayed in seclusion, alone and without distraction, practicing diligently. Because of staying in seclusion, alone and without distraction, practicing diligently, I then attained light and saw forms, but that light and seeing of forms quickly disappeared.
Aniruddha!
I further thought like this:
'What affliction is there in my mind that causes me to lose concentration and lose my eyes? When my eyes disappeared, the light and seeing of forms that I originally attained quickly disappeared.'
Aniruddha!
I further thought like this:

'There are various thoughts arising in my mind, and because of these various thoughts, I lose concentration and the eye of insight is extinguished. When the eye of insight is extinguished, the light and vision of forms that I originally attained are also extinguished.'
Anuruddha!
I should now think like this:

'I will not give rise to doubts in my mind, nor will I give rise to thoughts of physical illness, nor will I give rise to thoughts of sleepiness, nor will I give rise to thoughts of excessive diligence, nor will I give rise to thoughts of excessive laziness, nor will I give rise to thoughts of fear, nor will I give rise to thoughts of joy, nor will I give rise to thoughts of self-importance, nor will I give rise to various thoughts.'
Anuruddha!

I wanted to avoid this affliction, so I stayed in seclusion, alone and focused, practicing diligently. Because I stayed in seclusion, alone and focused, practicing diligently, I attained light and saw forms, but that light and seeing of forms disappeared again.
Anuruddha!
I had this thought:
'What affliction is there in my mind that causes me to lose concentration and lose my eyes? When my eyes disappeared, the light and seeing of forms that I originally attained disappeared again.'
Anuruddha!
I had this further thought:

'There is an affliction in my mind of not contemplating forms. Because of this affliction of not contemplating forms, I lost concentration and lost my eyes. When my eyes disappeared, the light and seeing of forms that I originally attained disappeared again.'
Anuruddha!
I should now think like this:

'I do not give rise to doubts in my mind, I do not give rise to the affliction of absent-mindedness, I do not give rise to the affliction of bodily illness, I do not give rise to the affliction of sleepiness, I do not give rise to the affliction of excessive diligence, I do not give rise to the affliction of excessive laziness, I do not give rise to the affliction of fear, I do not give rise to the affliction of joy, I also do not give rise to the affliction of self-importance, I do not give rise to the affliction of various thoughts, and I also do not give rise to the affliction of not contemplating form.'
Aniruddha!

In order to not give rise to these afflictions, I then stayed in seclusion, alone and without distraction, practicing diligently. Because of staying in seclusion, alone and without distraction, practicing diligently, I then attained light and saw forms.
Aniruddha!

If my mind gives rise to doubts and afflictions, their minds will be purified, free from thoughts of physical illness, sleepiness, excessive diligence, excessive laziness, fear, joy, arrogance, various thoughts, and not observing the mind's afflictions, their minds will be purified.
Anuruddha!
I further thought like this:

'I should cultivate and learn the three concentrations, cultivate and learn the concentration with initial and sustained thought, cultivate and learn the concentration with no initial thought but sustained thought only, and cultivate and learn the concentration with neither initial nor sustained thought.'
Anuruddha!

I then cultivated and learned the three concentrations, cultivated and learned the concentration with initial and sustained thought, cultivated and learned the concentration with no initial thought but sustained thought only, and cultivated and learned the concentration with neither initial nor sustained thought;

if I cultivate and learn the concentration with initial and sustained thought, my mind will follow and incline towards the concentration with no initial thought but sustained thought only, in this way I will certainly not lose this wisdom and insight.
Anuruddha!
Thus, knowing and seeing like this, I practiced and studied the concentration with applied thought and sustained thought all day and night.
Anuruddha!

At that time, when I practiced this abiding practice, if I cultivated the concentration with applied thought and sustained thought, my mind inclined towards the concentration without applied thought and sustained thought. Thus, I would not lose this knowledge and insight.
Anuruddha!
Thus, knowing and seeing like this, I practiced and studied the concentration with applied thought and sustained thought all day and night.
Anuruddha!
At that time, when I practiced this abiding practice.
Anuruddha!

If I cultivated the concentration with little applied thought and sustained thought, my mind inclined towards the concentration with applied thought and sustained thought. Thus, I would not lose this knowledge and insight.
Anuruddha!
Thus, knowing and seeing like this, I practiced and studied the concentration with little applied thought and sustained thought all day and night.
Anuruddha!

When I practiced this abiding, if I cultivated the concentration of no perception and little thought, my mind inclined towards the concentration of no perception and no thought. In this way, I would not lose this knowledge and insight.
Anuruddha!
After knowing and understanding this, I practiced the concentration of no perception and little thought all day and night.
Anuruddha!
At that time, I practiced this abiding.
Anuruddha!
If I cultivated the concentration of no perception and no thought, my mind inclined towards the concentration of perception and thought. In this way, I would not lose this knowledge and insight.
Anuruddha!
After knowing and understanding this, I practiced the concentration of no perception and no thought all day and night.
Anuruddha!

When I practiced this abiding, if I cultivated the concentration of neither perception nor non-perception, my mind inclined towards the concentration of neither perception nor non-perception. In this way, I did not lose this knowledge and insight.
Anuruddha!
After I knew and understood this, I practiced the concentration of neither perception nor non-perception all day and night, all day and night.
Anuruddha!
At that time, I practiced this abiding.
Anuruddha!
Sometimes I know light but do not see form.
Anuruddha!
I thought like this:
'What causes and conditions lead to knowing light but not seeing form?'
Anuruddha!
I further thought like this:
'If I recollect the characteristics of light but do not recollect the characteristics of form, then I will know light but not see form.'
Anuruddha!
Thus, knowing this, I knew light all day, all night, and all day and night, but did not see forms.
Anuruddha!
At that time, I practiced this abiding practice.
Anuruddha!
Sometimes I saw forms but did not know light.
Anuruddha!
I thought like this:
'What causes and conditions make me see forms but not know light?'
Anuruddha!
I further thought like this:
'If I recollect the characteristics of forms but do not recollect the characteristics of light, then I will know forms but not know light.'
Anuruddha!
Thus, knowing this, I knew forms all day, all night, and all day and night, but did not know light.
Anuruddha!
At that time, I practiced this abiding practice.
Anuruddha!
Sometimes I knew a little light and also saw a little form.
Anuruddha!
I thought like this:
'What are the causes and conditions for my knowing little light and also seeing little form?
Anuruddha!
I further thought like this:
'If I enter concentration little, because of entering concentration little, my eye is purified little, because my eye is purified little, I know little light and also see little form.'
Anuruddha!
Thus I knew like this, having known like this, I knew little light for a whole day, a whole night, a whole day and night, and also saw little form.
Anuruddha!
At that time, I practiced this dwelling practice.
Anuruddha!
Sometimes I extensively knew light and also extensively saw form.
Anuruddha!
I thought like this:
'What are the causes and conditions for my extensively knowing light and also extensively seeing form?
Anuruddha!
I further thought like this:

'If I enter samÄdhi extensively, due to entering samÄdhi extensively, my eyes will be purified extensively. Due to my eyes being purified extensively, I will extensively know light and also extensively see forms.
Anuruddha!
Thus I know thus. I extensively know light and also extensively see forms throughout the day, throughout the night, and throughout the day and night.
Anuruddha!
At that time, I practiced this abiding practice.
Anuruddha!

If doubts arise in my mind, I attain mental purity. I have no thoughts of physical illness, sleepiness, excessive diligence, excessive laziness, fear, joy, or arrogance. I do not give rise to various thoughts or observe forms as mental afflictions.

They attained mental purity, and cultivated and greatly cultivated the concentration with initial and sustained thought, the concentration without initial thought but with sustained thought, the concentration without initial or sustained thought, the concentration of one-pointedness, the concentration of mixed concentration, the concentration of little concentration, and the concentration of vast immeasurable concentration.

I knew and saw the extreme clarity and purity of my birth, I directed my mind towards concentration and abided in it, diligently cultivating the factors of the path, knowing that birth was ended, the holy life had been established, what was to be done had been done, there would be no more of this mundane state, knowing as it really is.
Anuruddha!
At that time, I practiced this abiding practice.
The Buddha spoke thus.
The Venerable Anuruddha, the Venerable Nandiya, and the Venerable Kimbila, having heard the Buddha's words, joyfully undertook to follow them.
